title: What Joe Thornton said about the Bruins during his Hall of Fame induction speech
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Joe Thornton began his NHL career with the Boston Bruins, playing eight seasons and scoring 454 points in 532 games.
During his Hall of Fame speech, Thornton thanked the Bruins alumni, including Wayne Cashman and Johnny Bucyk, for their mentorship.
Thornton praised Boston fans for their support, expressing gratitude for his time with the Bruins in his enshrinement speech.

title: Several key Patriots players still limited in latest injury report
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Key players Kayshon Boutte and Rhamondre Stevenson are limited in the Patriots' injury report ahead of Thursday's game.
Austin Hooper (concussion) and Joshua Farmer (ankle) did not practice; multiple players participated on a limited basis.
TreVeyon Henderson, the likely starting running back, participated fully despite a knee injury, along with other players.

title: Man, ‘significant’ number of birds and snakes killed in Methuen house fire, department says
author: Sana Muneer
bullets: A house fire in Methuen killed a man and a significant number of birds and snakes early Tuesday.
Firefighters responded at 2:20 a.m. to 38 Atkinson St., battling the blaze for four hours.
The fire's cause is under investigation by Methuen fire and police departments, and State Police investigators.

title: What readers say Boston Mayor Michelle Wu should prioritize in her next term
author: Annie Jonas
bullets: Housing affordability and public safety are top priorities for Boston residents as Mayor Michelle Wu begins her second term.
A Boston.com poll showed 49% of respondents want Wu to address affordability and safety, with many citing high living costs.
Residents also highlight the need for improved city infrastructure and concern over traffic issues due to new developments.

title: Pay transparency is now law in Massachusetts. What does it mean for you?
author: Pattie Hunt Sinacole
bullets: Massachusetts enacted a pay transparency law on October 29, requiring employers to disclose salary ranges in job postings.
The law applies to employers with 25 or more employees, covering promotions, transfers, and remote positions tied to Massachusetts.
Violations of the law can lead to investigations and penalties by the Massachusetts Attorney General, with a grace period for compliance.

title: Salem woman who ran ‘creepy creations’ shop to plead guilty in Harvard morgue scandal
author: Abby Patkin
bullets: Katrina Maclean of Salem pleads guilty to charges related to stolen human remains from Harvard Medical School morgue.
Maclean, owner of Kat’s Creepy Creations, is accused of selling body parts obtained from morgue manager Cedric Lodge.
Prosecutors suggest a 12-month sentence; Maclean's plea deal allows her to appeal a ruling on the case's legality.

title: Tell us: What’s the best New England town for a winter weekend getaway?
author: Kristi Palma
bullets: New England is highlighted as a top destination for winter weekend getaways with diverse options like ski towns and cozy accommodations.
Boston and other towns such as Nantucket, Woodstock, and Bar Harbor are noted for their winter beauty by Country Living.
Boston.com invites readers to share their favorite New England winter getaways, potentially featuring responses in upcoming articles.

title: Boston ranks among best U.S. cities for Thanksgiving — and tops New England
author: Frances Klemm
bullets: Boston ranked 18th in WalletHub's study of the top 100 Thanksgiving destinations in the U.S.
Boston was the only New England city on the list, praised for its vibrant restaurant scene.
WalletHub noted Boston's high volunteer rates and numerous highly-rated restaurants as key factors.

title: Five years after debuting ‘Java with Jimmy,’ host James Hills isn’t slowing down
author: Ross Cristantiello
bullets: James 'Jimmy' Hills' show 'Java with Jimmy' began as a Facebook livestream discussing COVID-19 impacts on Boston's communities of color.
Hills, 54, serves as an adviser to Mayor Michelle Wu and interviews diverse guests, including political leaders and community organizers.
Hills plans to expand 'Java with Jimmy' into a larger platform akin to BET, while continuing his commitment to community engagement.

title: Roman Anthony earns a third place finish for AL Rookie of the Year
author: Aidan Buchanan
bullets: Roman Anthony finished third in AL Rookie of the Year voting behind Nick Kurtz and Jacob Wilson.
Anthony played 71 games with a .292 average, 8 home runs, and 32 RBIs, despite an injury-shortened season.
Anthony signed an eight-year, $130 million extension with the Red Sox in August.
